metadata.titleEn: ChinaHighO3: High-resolution and High-quality Ground-level MDA8 O3 Dataset for China (2000-2023)
metadata.description: ChinaHighO3 is one of the series of long-term, full-coverage, high-resolution, and high-quality datasets of ground-level air pollutants for China (i.e., ChinaHighAirPollutants, CHAP). It is generated from the big data (e.g., ground-based measurements, satellite remote sensing products, atmospheric reanalysis, and model simulations) using artificial intelligence by considering the spatiotemporal heterogeneity of air pollution. This is the big data-derived seamless (spatial coverage = 100%) daily, monthly, and yearly 1 km (i.e., D1K, M1K, and Y1K) ground-level maximum 8-hour average (MDA8) O3 dataset in China from 2000 to present. This dataset yields a high quality with a cross-validation coefficient of determination (CV-R2) of 0.89 and a root-mean-square error (RMSE) of 15.77 µg m-3 on a daily basis. Note that this dataset is continuously updated, and if you want to apply for more data or have any questions, please contact me (Email: weijing_rs@163.com; weijing@umd.edu).
metadata.instructions: File Name: The data is stored in the NetCDF file format, and the file name is CHAP_O3_ab_yyyymmdd_V1.nc, where a represents time resolution (D represents daily data, M represents monthly data, Y represents annual data), b represents spatial resolution (1K represents 1km), yyyy represents year, mm represents month, and dd represents day. Data reading method: Python, Matlab, IDL, and other programming methods can be used to convert files from NC to TIF. The data coordinate system is WGS-1984, with a background value of 65535.

background: Ozone (O3) is an important trace and greenhouse gas in the atmosphere, posing a threat to the ecological environment and human health at the ground level. Tropospheric O3 (< 12 km above the ground) is mainly produced by anthropogenic activities, affecting radiative forcing at a global scale with implications on climate change. Exposure to high surface O3 levels is highly related to increased human health risks, including cardiovascular and respiratory diseases. It also affects the ecosystem and agricultural production, e.g., inhibiting plant growth, promoting leaf senescence, and affecting crop yields. Since the middle of the twentieth century, many countries around the world have observed tropospheric and ground-level O3. In 2013, the Chinese Ministry of Environment and Ecology (MEE) established a national air quality observation network to monitor real-time O3, particulate matter (PM), and other near-surface air pollutants. However, the construction and maintenance of ground networks require substantial manpower and material resources. Satellite remote sensing can make up for such a deficiency by providing spatially continuous atmospheric O3 distributions. Near-surface O3 typically accounts for only a few percent of total column O3, and the retrieval sensitivity to near-surface O3 from ultraviolet measurements is limited. It is thus particularly difficult to extract near-surface O3 concentrations from satellite measurements.
research objective: This study offers a new perspective to estimate ground-level O3 from solar radiation intensity and surface temperature by employing an extended ensemble learning of the space-time extremely randomized trees (STET) model, together with ground-based observations, remote sensing products, atmospheric reanalysis, and an emission inventory.
challenges: Large-scale and long-term studies of O3 pollution in China are few due to highly limited direct ground and satellite measurements. However, the construction and maintenance of ground networks require substantial manpower and material resources. Near-surface O3 typically accounts for only a few percent of total column O3, and the retrieval sensitivity to near-surface O3 from ultraviolet measurements is limited. It is thus particularly difficult to extract near-surface O3 concentrations from satellite measurements.
methods: In this study, daily MDA8 O₃ concentrations were first estimated to examine daily and interannual changes in surface O₃ in China. Since hourly ground measurements and core input predictors (i.e., downwelling solar surface radiation and air temperature) are available, our model can be employed to reasonably predict hourly surface O₃ concentrations.
dataset: A full-coverage (100%), high-resolution (10 km) and high-quality daily maximum 8-h average (MDA8) ground-level O3 dataset covering China (called ChinaHighO3) from 2013 to 2020 was generated.
findings: Our MDA8 O3 estimates (predictions) are reliable, with an average out-of-sample (out-of-station) coefficient of determination of 0.87 (0.80) and root-mean-square error of 17.10 (21.10) μg/m3 in China. The unique advantage of the full coverage of our dataset allowed us to accurately capture a short-term severe O3 pollution exposure event that took place from 23 April to 8 May in 2020. Also, a rapid increase and recovery of O3 concentrations associated with variations in anthropogenic emissions were seen during and after the COVID-19 lockdown, respectively. Trends in O3 concentration showed an average growth rate of 2.49 μg/m3/yr (p < 0.001) from 2013 to 2020, along with the continuous expansion of polluted areas exceeding the daily O3 standard (i.e., MDA8 O3 = 160 μg/m3). Summertime O3 concentrations and the probability of occurrence of daily O3 pollution have significantly increased since 2015, especially in the North China Plain and the main air pollution transmission belt (i.e., the “2 + 26” cities). However, a decline in both was seen in 2020, mainly due to the coordinated control of air pollution and ongoing COVID-19 effects.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method that effectively estimates ground-level O3 using alternative predictors like solar radiation intensity and surface temperature?
Example.Answer: An example of a data collection method that estimates ground-level O3 is the use of an extended ensemble learning model, specifically the space-time extremely randomized trees (STET) model, which incorporates solar radiation intensity, surface temperature, ground-based observations, remote sensing products, atmospheric reanalysis, and emission inventories.

Example.Question: Could you illustrate a challenge that arises when trying to collect large-scale, long-term ground-level O3 data and a possible approach to overcome it?
Example.Answer: A challenge in collecting large-scale, long-term ground-level O3 data is the limited direct ground and satellite measurements, which require substantial resources to maintain. A possible approach to overcome this challenge is employing AI technology to integrate diverse data sources like ground-based observations and satellite data to produce a seamless dataset.

Example.Question: Provide an example of a potential dataset that offers full coverage and high-resolution data of ground-level O3 concentrations over a large geographical area.
Example.Answer: An example of such a dataset is the high-resolution daily maximum 8-hour average (MDA8) ground-level O3 dataset covering China from 2013 to 2020, known as the ChinaHighO3 dataset, which provides full coverage and captures short-term pollution events effectively.

Definition.Question: What is the significance of using artificial intelligence in generating high-resolution air pollutant datasets?
Definition.Answer: Artificial intelligence is used to generate high-resolution air pollutant datasets by leveraging surface solar radiation intensity and air temperature as main predictors, along with ground-based observations, remote sensing products, atmospheric reanalysis, and an emission inventory.

Definition.Question: What does the term 'maximum 8-hour sliding average O3 data' represent in the context of air quality monitoring?
Definition.Answer: The term 'maximum 8-hour sliding average O3 data' represents a calculated average of ground-level ozone concentrations over a period of eight hours, used to monitor and assess air quality in the context of potential human health risks and environmental impacts.

Definition.Question: What challenges are associated with extracting near-surface O3 concentrations from satellite measurements?
Definition.Answer: Challenges associated with extracting near-surface O3 concentrations from satellite measurements include the limited sensitivity of ultraviolet measurements to near-surface O3, which typically accounts for only a few percent of total column O3, making it difficult to accurately determine ground-level concentrations.

Comparison.Question: What are the similarities and differences in the challenges faced when using satellite remote sensing versus ground-based observations to estimate near-surface O3 concentrations?
Comparison.Answer: Both satellite remote sensing and ground-based observations face challenges in estimating near-surface O3 concentrations. Satellite remote sensing struggles with limited retrieval sensitivity to near-surface O3 from ultraviolet measurements, whereas ground-based observations require significant manpower and material resources for network construction and maintenance.

Interpretation.Question: How do the integration of ground-based observations and remote sensing products contribute to overcoming the challenges in generating comprehensive O3 datasets?
Interpretation.Answer: The integration of ground-based observations with remote sensing products helps address the challenges of limited direct ground and satellite measurements. By combining these data sources with atmospheric reanalysis and emission inventories, researchers can produce a seamless, high-resolution dataset that provides full coverage of O3 concentrations, enabling detailed analysis of pollution events and trends over time.

Interpretation.Question: What insights can be drawn about the temporal trends of O3 pollution in China from the analysis of high-quality datasets?
Interpretation.Answer: Analysis of high-quality datasets reveals that O3 pollution in China has shown a significant upward trend, with an average growth rate of 2.49 μg/m3 per year from 2013 to 2020. The data also highlight short-term pollution events and the impact of anthropogenic emissions, such as changes observed during and after the COVID-19 lockdown, indicating the dataset's utility in tracking pollution dynamics and informing policy decisions.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why are large-scale and long-term studies of O3 pollution in China limited?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Large-scale and long-term studies of O3 pollution in China are few due to highly limited direct ground and satellite measurements. Additionally, the construction and maintenance of ground networks require substantial manpower and material resources.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the primary objective behind employing artificial intelligence techniques to predict ground-level O3 concentrations using solar radiation intensity and air temperature?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The main objective is to provide a new perspective for estimating ground-level O3 by leveraging AI techniques, specifically an extended ensemble learning model, to overcome the limitations of direct ground and satellite measurements and create a spatially continuous and high-resolution dataset.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to generate a high-resolution dataset for ground-level O3 concentrations over China from 2000 to the present?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Generating such a dataset is crucial because it allows researchers to examine daily and interannual changes in surface O3, facilitates the study of large-scale and long-term O3 pollution trends in China, and helps in capturing significant pollution events and analyzing variations due to factors like anthropogenic emissions.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methods are employed to estimate ground-level O3 concentrations using solar radiation intensity and surface temperature, and how are these methods integrated with other data sources?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Ground-level O3 concentrations are estimated using extended ensemble learning of the space-time extremely randomized trees (STET) model. This method integrates ground-based observations, remote sensing products, atmospheric reanalysis, and an emission inventory to provide reliable estimates.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedural challenges exist in constructing and maintaining ground networks for monitoring O3 pollution, and how does satellite remote sensing complement these efforts?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Constructing and maintaining ground networks require substantial manpower and resources. Satellite remote sensing complements these efforts by providing spatially continuous atmospheric O3 distributions, although it remains challenging to extract near-surface O3 concentrations from satellite measurements due to limited retrieval sensitivity.

Enablement.Question: What role does artificial intelligence play in enabling the creation of high-resolution air pollution datasets?
Enablement.Answer: Artificial intelligence techniques are utilized to produce high-resolution air pollution datasets by using surface solar radiation intensity and air temperature as main predictive factors, combined with ground-based observations, atmospheric reanalysis, and emission inventories.

Enablement.Question: In what ways do downwelling solar surface radiation and air temperature serve as core predictors in the estimation of surface ozone concentrations?
Enablement.Answer: Downwelling solar surface radiation and air temperature are core predictors that enable the estimation of hourly surface ozone concentrations, allowing for the examination of daily and interannual changes in surface ozone levels.

Expectation.Question: Why might the retrieval sensitivity to near-surface O3 from ultraviolet measurements be limited in estimating ground-level O3 concentrations?
Expectation.Answer: Near-surface O3 typically accounts for only a few percent of total column O3, making it particularly difficult to extract near-surface O3 concentrations from satellite measurements due to limited retrieval sensitivity.

Expectation.Question: What challenges could arise from the large-scale and long-term studies of O3 pollution in China using direct ground and satellite measurements?
Expectation.Answer: Large-scale and long-term studies of O3 pollution in China are few due to highly limited direct ground and satellite measurements, compounded by the substantial manpower and material resources required for the construction and maintenance of ground networks.

Expectation.Question: How can artificial intelligence techniques, like ensemble learning models, improve the estimation of ground-level O3 concentrations?
Expectation.Answer: Artificial intelligence techniques, such as ensemble learning models, can improve the estimation of ground-level O3 concentrations by utilizing predictors like solar radiation intensity and surface temperature, combined with ground-based observations, remote sensing products, atmospheric reanalysis, and an emission inventory.

Judgmental.Question: How effective do you think the use of artificial intelligence is in predicting ground-level O3 concentrations using solar radiation intensity and surface temperature as main predictors?
Judgmental.Answer: The use of artificial intelligence in predicting ground-level O3 concentrations is considered effective, as indicated by the high coefficient of determination (R2 = 0.89) and a relatively low root mean square error (RMSE = 15.77 µg/m3) achieved through the model.

Judgmental.Question: What challenges do you foresee in maintaining the accuracy and reliability of O3 data collection in the long term, considering the reliance on both ground-based observations and satellite data?
Judgmental.Answer: Challenges in maintaining accuracy and reliability include the limited sensitivity of satellite measurements to near-surface O3, as well as the substantial manpower and material resources required for maintaining ground-based observation networks. Additionally, long-term consistency in data collection methods and technological advancements are crucial.

Judgmental.Question: In your opinion, what potential methods or datasets could be integrated to enhance the spatial and temporal resolution of O3 pollution data collection?
Judgmental.Answer: Potential methods or datasets that could enhance data resolution include integrating more detailed remote sensing products, expanding the ground-based observation network, and using advanced ensemble learning models that incorporate diverse environmental predictors to achieve higher spatial (e.g., 1 km) and temporal (daily, monthly) resolutions.

Request/Directive.Question: Please analyze the challenges faced in extracting near-surface O3 concentrations from satellite measurements and suggest potential methods to improve accuracy in this data collection method.
Request/Directive.Answer: The challenges in extracting near-surface O3 concentrations from satellite measurements include the limited retrieval sensitivity to near-surface O3 from ultraviolet measurements, as near-surface O3 typically accounts for only a few percent of total column O3. To improve accuracy, employing an ensemble learning model that integrates solar radiation intensity and surface temperature, along with ground-based observations, remote sensing products, atmospheric reanalysis, and an emission inventory, could enhance the estimation of ground-level O3.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore the potential for expanding datasets related to ground-level O3 by incorporating new technologies or methodologies, and assess the impact of such expansions on research outcomes.
Request/Directive.Answer: Expanding datasets related to ground-level O3 could involve incorporating advanced remote sensing technologies, such as high-resolution satellite imagery or novel sensor networks, to enhance spatial and temporal coverage. Using machine learning algorithms to integrate these diverse data sources could further refine predictions. Such expansions could significantly improve the accuracy and reliability of O3 estimates, allowing for better monitoring of pollution events and understanding of trends, which in turn could inform more effective policy decisions and interventions.
